PART 1. COUNTRY ISSUES
A. Backgroundand Transitionto Peace
1. Liberia had been a middle-income country before the civil war began in late 1989. Fifteen years o f brutal conflict devastated the country's economy, its physical infrastructure, and its human assets. In August 2003, the warring parties ended hostilities with the signing o f the Comprehensive Peace Agreement (CPA) in Accra, Ghana, and a National Transitional Government (NTGL) was established to administer a two-year interim period leading to national elections inOctober 2005. The UnitedNations Mission inLiberia (UNMIL)was created and was given the mandate to support the implementation o f the peace process. Over the last two and a half years, the peace in Liberia has been made possible inlarge part by the presence o f the 15,000 UNMILtroops stationedthere.
2. Liberia today i s one o f Africa's poorest nations, with a GDP per capita o f approximately $151. While accurate data i s not available, it is estimated that close to one million people fled from cities, villages, and towns to the neighboring countries o f Guinea, Sierra Leone, Cote' d'Ivoire, Ghana and Nigeria, and other countries'. Over 350,000 people moved into Internally Displaced Camps (IDC) across the country. The subsequent social and human capital costs have been enormous.
3. In December 2003, the UNDP and the World Bank undertook a joint mission to conduct a needs assessment for Liberia. This led to the development o f a Results Focused Transitional Framework (RFTF) which served as a strategic plan for the NTGL, as a partnership agreement between Liberia and its donor partners, and as a time-bound management tool for tracking progress in critical areas. These activities in the RFTF were organized by cluster, and the Bank took the lead in the Infrastructure and Economic Management clusters. With a lead role in Infrastructure, the Bank agreed to undertake assessments o f the emergency needs in transport, power, water, and telecommunications. In every sector emergency works as well as longer-term development needs were identified.
4. Despite efforts within the framework o f the RFTF, the primary challenge for the transitional Government remained the inability to reign in high incidences o f corruption, non-transparency and financial mismanagement at all levels o f Government. The deteriorating economic and fiduciary governance placed Liberia's recovery at risk. The response o f the NTGL and its development partners responded by developing the Governance and Economic Management Assistance Program (GEMAP) which was backed by the Security Council in a resolution passed inJune, 2005.
5. The GEMAP has introduced measures to strengthen fiscal administration and improve transparency and accountability by securing Liberia's revenue base and improving budgeting and expenditure management. Steadfast implementation o f the GEMAP, together with strong performance under the staff-monitored program (SMP), would pave the way toward the de- escalation o f the IMF's remedial measures against Liberia and the normalization o f relations with International Financial Institutions (IFIs). In addition, the successful implementation o f GEMAP
'Joint Needs Assessment Report, 2004
6  i s expected to constitute an important step towards lifting o f UNsanctions on diamond and timber exports'. Following the elections, the new Government o f Liberia (GOL) endorsed the GEMAP as a necessary step in enhancing governance practices and has already made progress in budget management, revenue generation and concession reviews during the first few months inoffice. In the context o f the fiscal disarray inherited by the Government, the actions taken to strengthen revenue collection and public expenditure management (through the enforcement o f pre-shipment inspections, reestablishment o f the Cash Management Committee, and prudent budget allocations for line ministries) are commendable.
6. In October-November 2005, legislative and presidential elections were held, leading to the inauguration on January 6, 2006 o f Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf. The new Government o f Liberia (GOL) has embraced the GEMAP as a necessary instrument to begin tackling the financial management challenges they face. Government has already made progress during the first few months in office. Inthe context o f the fiscal disarray inherited by the Government, the actions taken to strengthen revenue collection and public expenditure management (through the enforcement o f pre-shipment inspections, reestablishment o f the Cash Management Committee, and prudentbudget allocations for line ministries) are commendable.
7. In light o f the progress on economic reforms under the new Government, the Government and the IMF staff reached an agreement on policies to be implemented under a Staff Monitored Program (SMP), covering February-September 2006. If sufficient indications o f support from donors are forthcoming, strong performance under the SMP could form the basis for a subsequent program, which inturn could lead to the eventual arrears clearance and the resolution o f Liberia's debt overhang. Arrears clearance would restore normal relations between Liberia and the I F I s and would renew access to regular IDA-resources. This proposed pre-arrears clearance grant i s designed to help the Government restore critical infrastructure and basic services and bridge the funding gap inthe interimperiodprior to new IDA-resources becoming available.
8. In preparation for a new engagement between Government and development partners, Government constituted the Liberia Reconstruction and Development Committee (LRDC) as the main body to design, develop, coordinate and monitor the implementation o f a results-based national reconstruction and development program. The LRDC i s chaired by the President and involves key GOL Ministers as well as. It i s organized around four pillars: i)Security, ii) Economic Revitalization, iii)Governance and Rule o f Law, and iv) Infrastructure and Basic Services. The Bank i s a Co-Chair o f the Economic Revitalization and the Infrastructureand Basic Services Committees. The latter, chaired by the Minister o f Public Works includes all infi-astructure sectors as well as health and education. On the Government's side, only the four leading ministers and the Secretariat o f the Presidency sit at the LRDC, while coordination among ministries operating within a given pillar takes place within the four sub-committees. In the case o f the Infrastructure and Basic Services Pillar, therefore, initial sector trade-offs in the use o f donor resources are discussed within the pillar, among the concerned ministers and donors, prior to reachingthe LRDC, generating a more systematic and orderly decision-makingprocess.
9. At the first meeting o f the LRDC inFebruary 2006, the President affirmed the Government's commitment to develop a robust PRSP that will articulate priorities for public spending on social and strategic areas. She requested that international partners assist in the process leading to a PRSP by June 2006.
The UNembargo o n the export o f timber and diamonds was imposed inDecember 2003 to stop the financing of armed conflict inLiberia and the sub-region and was renewed inNovember 2005. The next mid-term review o f the sanctions will take place inJune 2006.
7  B. Economic and Social Impact of the Conflict
10. The challenges facing the new Government are immense as they try to rebuild the country's infrastructure, restore basic financial management, and mend the social fabric that was destroyed during the war. Regional conflict, still present in CGte d'Ivoire, continues to threaten the fragile peace in Liberia as well as in Sierra Leone. The decades o f conflict, conflict-driven migration and a heritage o f corruption have undermined domestic capacity and drained the pool o f skilled human resources, many o f whom left the country
11, Following a sharp decline ineconomic activity in2003, real GDP continues to recover (2.6% in2004 and 5.3% in2005). However, the recovery of agricultural activity has been sporadic due to the slow return of refugees to rural areas and largely destroyed or non-existent infrastructure. T w o o f the country's major sources o f export revenues and fiscal receipts (diamonds and forest products) are under international sanctions by the UN Security Council due to their past role in financing conflict in the region. Unemployment i s estimated at 85%3. Poverty i s widespread, The share o f people living on less that US$l/day has increased from 55% in 19974to 76% in 20015. Income-generating opportunities are limited as a result o f losses incurred during the conflict resulting in a narrow economic base. For example, the country's rural and urban road networks providing vital farm to market access have not been maintained or repaired for decades. At the same time, the prospects for capital formation and entrepreneurship have been severely undercut creating disincentives for private investment. Access to commercial capital i s almost non- existent. Basic education and health care remain unavailable or unaffordable for most children and people. 8  C. Sector Issues
C.l Transport Sector
C1.1 Overview
12. Prior to the civil war the transport sector in Liberia included road and railway networks, a network o f operational airports and aerodromes, and several ports. Today, the railway network i s destroyed does not exist, civil aviation i s limited to international and regional flights using Monrovia with only UN flights operating domestically, and the Port o f Monrovia i s the only operational port in the country. Duringthe years o f conflict, the sector was unable to undertake regular routine and periodic maintenance activities. Partial rehabilitation and new construction were sporadic and limited in scope. As a result o f the chronic underinvestment and lack o f maintenance the rehabilitation requirements o f the sector have already surpassed emergency conditions. On nearly every road link, in the ports and at the airports, lack o f regular maintenance causes emergency conditions on a daily basis.
13. The roads sub-sector i s by far the most important sector in terms o f freight volumes and passengers transported. Maritime transport i s restricted to importlexport activities in the Port o f Monrovia, while domestic civil aviation activities are nearly non-existent. The railway sector was developed in support o f inland iron ore mining activities and it i s expected that its revival will depend solely on similar developments. Such investments are expected to be funded by the private sector.
14. The state of the transportation infrastructure in Liberia directly affects its potential for economic development and trade facilitation. International road links are poor, farm to market access i s poor and, in many previously productive agricultural areas, impossible duringthe rainy season. Travel time i s extremely long, and upcountry areas are completely cut o f f in the months o f April to September. With UN sanctions on timber and diamond production and export expected to be lifted soon, demands on the transportation network will skyrocket.
15. Accessibility impacts security. UNMIL, whose mandate i s to guarantee security, i s continuously re-aligning resources to emergency repairs on the primary and secondary road networks usingits civilian and military engineers. The quality o f these emergency interventions i s often not good and the roads soon return to their original poor condition.
16. The Government recognizes the urgency o f the situation and has requested donors' assistance for the sector. Starting in 2005, the Bank financed the technical assessment o f two o f the main road corridors in the country (Monrovia-Buchanan and Monrovia-Ganta), the Port o f Monrovia and the Roberts InternationalAirport (Infrastructure TA, TFLIB-funded). These studies identified emergency works and developed bidding documents that have been shared with donors. Donor support pledged thus far i s not enough to re-instate transport services to pre-emergency levels.
C1.2 Road Sub-sector
17. Rebuilding the road sector i s also a top Government priority. The TFLIB-financed technical assessment focused on two primary road links; Monrovia-Buchanan (the link between the two largest population centres) and Monrovia-Ganta-Guinea Border (the most important road linking Monrovia with the interior and with one neighbouring country). The assessment identified emergency works on these links in excess o f $20 million including bridge repairs, pothole and other pavement repairs, drainage repairs and basic road safety activities like painting lane markings.

19. Government has not undertaken any road condition surveys since the beginning o f the conflict. Also, very little road maintenance was carried out during this time. Reports from donor agencies, NGOs and the Government confirm that most o f these roads are either ina poor or very poor condition.
20. The road network also includes a substantial bridge and culvert inventory with many bridges and culverts washed away, collapsed or badly damaged. Many more are inurgent need o f repair. Due to the war the MPW has not been able to undertake a formal bridge inspection for at least the last 20 years. NGOs and other donors are improving access to rural communities by re-instating the smaller culverts and bridges but large areas o f the country still have only limited access due to these missinglinksinthe road network.
21. The urban roads are also in a poor condition. The road condition inMonrovia is acute due to the high traffic volumes throughout the city. There are specific areas that experience congestion for most o f the day. The uncontrolled spread o f market places i s also a major contributor to the deteriorating traffic conditions.
C1.3 CivilAviation
22. Roberts International Airport (RIA), about 45 km outside Monrovia, is the only international airport in the country and the only airport open for fixed wing aircraft. James Spriggs Payne, located within Monrovia's city boundaries as well as several other airports are operated by and used only for UN flights to transport UN personnel and equipment. All other domestic civil aviation ceased duringthe years o f strife.
23. Before the war, Liberia had one operational international airline, Liberia Airways. However, it has since been closed and its assets sold off. At present, air traffic is sparse with only one international airline and three infrequent West African carriers servicing Liberia.
10  24. The TFLIB-financed technical assessment o f Roberts International Airport estimates the extent of the emergency works at about US$3.6 million. The most critical activity will be financed with TFLIB resources as Liberia Infrastructure Rehabilitation Project (LIRP) which i s currently under preparation.
C1.4 Ports
25. Liberia has five ports, including Monrovia, Buchanan, Greenville, Harper and Robertsport. Before the war these ports handled about 200,000 tons o f general cargo and around 400,000 tons of petroleum products per year. Inaddition, Monrovia and Buchananhandled all the bulkiron ore exports, and Buchanan and Greenville were responsible for most o f the timber exports.
26. The war and the international sanctions severely disrupted port operations while extensive looting rendered most o f the facilities useless. Today, nearly 100% o f the fuel, dry-bulk and container trade i s handled in the Port o f Monrovia. The other ports are barely operational with trans-shipment activities between Monrovia and the four smaller ports beingnegligible.
27. The TFLIB-financed technical assessment o f the Port o f Monrovia identified emergency works in excess o f US$30 million. The LIRP, currently under preparation, proposes to support the most critical repairs costed at about USS7.0 million.
C1.5 Railways
28. The railway network in Liberia was constructed by the mining companies to transport iron ore from the now closed iron ore mines at Mano River (Grand Cape Mount County), Bong Town (Bong County), and the Ganta-Yekepa area (Nimba County) to the ports o f Monrovia and Buchanan. The total length o f the network was about 500 km.The last mine closed soon after the war started in 1986. Since then tracks were left unattended.
29. Recently, international mining companies showed interest in re-opening the old mines and developing deposits in Guinea and Cote d'Ivoire. This suggests that the demand for a rail link to the coast may develop with firm decisions to establish mining activities at any o f these locations. Such developments are ideally suited for private sector development with the Yekepa-Buchanan- link and the rehabilitation and expansion of capacity at the port of Buchanan being the most likely.
C1.6 Institutional Framework
30. Up until 2006 with the inauguration o f the new Government, management o f the transport sector among several Ministries. The Ministry o f Transport (MOT) i s responsible for transport sector policy development and regulation. The responsibility for managing the proclaimed network was divided between two Ministries, the Ministry o f Public Works (MPW) being responsible for the primary and secondary roads and the Ministry of Rural Development being responsible for the feeder and farm to market roads. The new Government transferred all road infrastructure responsibilities to the Ministry o f Public Works (MPW).
31, Duringthe war these Ministries lost their capacity to manage their respective functions. They lost their data and documentation and currently rely on collective memory to determine road data. They were unable to undertake regular road condition assessments. They confirm that almost no road maintenance was done from 1986 to date. As a result, most roads are in a poor to very poor condition. All offices of the two new Ministries have been completely looted and there i s no equipment left. Both Ministries are in dire need o f all types o f basic office equipment, vehicles,
11  and specialised engineering gear. MPW has a small core o f technical and maintenance staff remaining from the periodprior to the war. However, the lack o f any kindo f equipment, years o f skills atrophy and very little training, limits the capacity o f the MPW to carry out most o f the tasks associated with reconstruction efforts. A report drafted by UNMIL (September 2004) shows that the MPW as a whole had about 2,240 employees prior to the war with only 943 remaining in September 2004. M P W executes its functions through 16 maintenance districts and also managed a RoadMaintenanceTraining Centre. These facilities have all been destroyed.
32. Additional to the emergency works Government identified the urgent need to rebuild the capacity o f the Ministry o f Public Works (MPW) to effectively manage the road network. This includes the provision o f equipment and systems as well as the development o f strategies that include a longer term vision for the sub-sector. The MPW i s one o f the two Ministries involved in the transport sector. MOT i s responsible for regulating the transport sector with MPW i s responsible for managing, amongst others, the nationalroadnetwork.
C2 Water sector
C2.1 Overview
33. Prior to the war, Monrovia (as well as several cities outside o f the capital) had a functioning, piped water supply system providing service via communal and individual water points. Monrovia even enjoyed a sewer network, which, decades later, continues to be uncommon in most o f West Africa. About 22,000 water connections were active at the time. Water services at communal water points were provided free o f charge and the responsible authority, the Public Utilities Authority (PUA), used to pass the cost o f the water services to the Government's account. Individual consumers were charged on a flat rate basis.
34. Since 1973 Liberia Water and Sewer Corporation (LWSC) i s responsible for dnnking water supply and sewerage services inMonrovia, secondary county-cities, and all rural areas o fLiberia. In 1980 a water treatment plant, at White Plains, and a closed ring of primary water mains were completed to provide a design capacity up to 16 million gallons (60,567 m') per day to Monrovia's 450,000 inhabitants at that time. The treatment plant was fed with raw water and electricity from the Mount Coffee Dam, about 8 km upstream. During the war the dam overtopped and broke, severely affecting the production capacity o f the purification plant. The dam's hydropower electricity supply was substituted by generator sets located at the plant and it now extracts raw water directly from the St. Paul River. Current production i s about 1.2 million gallons per day (4,542 m3/day), or about 7.5 % o f it i s original capacity-for a Monrovian population o f more than a million people. Only a small part o f Monrovia currently has piped water, with most water deliveredby truck. 35. A supplementary water supply o f two deep wellshore-holes were drilled in 1993 at the Eastern end o f town (capacity o f 27 and 22 m' per hour) from which clean water i s trucked and distributed to the Eastern suburbs. 36. The distribution network o f ductile or galvanized iron pipes in Monrovia has not been used since 1990 and has been seriously damaged, neglected, and i s in dire need o f substantial repairs. Currently, a large section o f the city extracts water from hand-dug public and private shallow wells. The UNDP estimates that there are more than 5,500 o f these wells, either open or covered and equipped with hand-pumps preventing a water crisis. 37. Between 1990 and 2004 the EC contributed approximately Euro 10 million for maintaining the water supply inMonrovia as an emergency support. Duringthat period, the Republic o f China contributed another US3.25 million for system rehabilitation. By late 2003, water production
12  and distribution for around 400,000 inhabitants costed the EC approximately Euro 120,000 per month. This expense had become a significant recurring cost for the EC, which had little recourse but to continue as the systemwould have collapsed completely ifturned over to the Government. This support does not include maintenance and rehabilitation costs o f the water infrastructure and equipment that continued to deteriorate. The Liberian Water and Sewer Corporation (LWSC), the Agency that took over operations from the PUA, has little financial and managerial capacity with financial management and accountability beingespecially weak.
38. Inthe midst o f the civil war in 1999, a "Demographic and Health Survey Report" found that only 2% o f the households inMonrovia had access to pipe-borne water intheir own dwelling and a another 9.3% o f the households had access to pipe-borne water from a public tap or a neighboring house. Only 31% o f the households acknowledged having access to safe drinking water, with the remaining population depending on shallow wells, springs, ponds or rivers for their drinking water. Today, following years o f looting, vandalism and neglect, access to clean water i s projected to be lower than in 1999. Monrovia's water treatment plant i s semi-operational and the pipe network i s in poor condition. Piped water i s available only in small pockets in Bushrod Island in Monrovia. The LWSC reports 560 active water connections including a few industrial bulk water consumers and UNMILtankers. The majority o f the 1+ million residents o f Monrovia use shallow wells and trucked water delivered at various points throughout the city and further re-sold by retail distributors. Monrovia's wastewater treatment plant and all pump stations are non-operational. Sewerage and surface water drainage channels and pipes in Monrovia have not been cleaned for years.
39. Theft levels and illegal connections to the remaining water supply network are very highand add to the already significant amount o f water loss due to system leakage and poor maintenance practices. At US$2.35/m3, the price for cash and carry water from the 5 kiosks (3 in Bushrod Island and 2 at Paynesville) are considerably higher than that o f house connections, selling water at US$0.7/m3. Trucked water i s sold at US$1.6/m3 at origin and re-sold from about US$3.20 to 9.25/m3 to the end-user (depending on the container size). Based on initial assessments cost recovery rate for potable water i s about US$1.19/m3. The current rates show that any improvement in the pipe network will lead to a decrease in the average cost o f water, thereby improving the general living conditions inLiberia.
C2.2 InstitutionalFramework
40. The LWSC i s responsible for the operation and management o f the water and piped sewerage systems. Urban and road drainage fall under the Ministry o f Public Works, while solid waste management i s governed by the Monrovia City Corporation.
41. The LWSC has never operated at cost recovery. Before the war, the Government provided a subsidy to the LWSC to offset Government obligations, but it was impossible to collect all payments due to political interference and low levels o f accountability. Significant losses were accumulated. Today, arrears are significant. The utility has accumulated a debt o f US$90 thousand to local commercial banks to cover operational costs, and approximately US$40 million outstanding credit from investors in the 70s. With the exception o f the short-term commercial debt (secured with payments from Coca-Cola and the Monrovia Brewery) no strategy for repayment exists. Water losses are significant and estimated at 60%. The collection rate i s low at 42% from the invoiced water. Government stopped subsidizingthe LWSC years ago.
13  42. Today, the LWSC employs about 150 staff and operates as a vertically integratedstate-owned utility. Operations are inefficient, administration and managerial practices are poor. The EC is supporting the utility and is providing technical expertise. Many issues remain outstanding e.g. financial recovery (collection o f revenues), capacity and overstaffing.
C3 Electricity Sector
C3.1 Overview
43. Liberia's pre-war installed capacity (hydro + thermal) was around 180 M Y , o f which about 75 MW was for Monrovia. Today, virtually all the infrastructure i s missinginthis sector, having been either destroyed or stolen. This includes the country's most cost-effective installation, a 60 MW hydro plant and associated dam at Mt.Coffee (20 miles from Monrovia). This installation is completely destroyed and looted, including one-third of the dam that washed away to the streambed.
44. Currently, the entire country is runningon individual diesel generators and a few small run- of-river hydro plants, total capacity has been estimated at 50 MW for the whole country. Diesel currently costs about $3.20 gallon inLiberia, thus electricity costs about $0.70/kWh-or 10 times as much as inmost industrial countries.
C3.2 Institutional Framework
45. The Liberia Electricity Corporation (LEC) i s responsible for the country's electricity supply and distribution. This sector falls under the Ministry o f Lands, Mines, Energy and Environment. The LEC i s a state owned enterprise, but has no assets, no customers and no revenues.
46. The LEC currently officially employs about 450 people, or likely 300 too many for its current and medium term needs. It i s also highly indebted, at about US$115 million and, with no revenue, will stay inthat condition for some time.
C3 Government Strategy
C3.1 Transport Sector
47. The Government identified the need for efficient road connections between Monrovia and the rest o f the country as central to achieving its reconstruction vision. It was declared a top priority because o f its direct impact on security and long-term peace. In addition, by improving road accessibility, Government aims to encourage and accelerate the process o f social and economic rehabilitation o f the affected populations, provide employment opportunities and field to market access for rural communities. Following the lifting o f the UNsanctions on diamonds and timber, the main road corridors linkingupcountry areas with the Port o f Monrovia i s expected to become critical to trade export.
The Government intends to develop a new strategy for the transport sector. This strategy should help address the inadequacy o f budget provisions for road maintenance by exploring opportunities for additional funding through road user charges, the possible establishment o f a dedicated Road Fund as well as the introduction o f efficient management o f the road sub-sector where the intention i s to outsource all maintenance, rehabilitation and construction works to contractors, with the Ministry retaining only a small team o f engineers for quick, emergency reaction. The possible introduction o f public private partnerships (PPP) will also be considered, specifically for major road corridors and bridges.

Mitigation: The project would package the works to generate such interest and would provide for additional dissemination to build private sector interest in these Bank-financed activities. Two options were considered, either to use a large size one contract in magnitude o f US$16-20 million or to use a number o f smaller works contracts. The preferable option would be three contracts, two for the emergency works on the primary roads and one for the works on bridges and culverts.
(iii) Donor Coordination may be dgjcult in the emergency environment: Due to the short preparation and implementation time proper donor coordination may not be possible for the water sector activities. Mitigation: The team will include in project preparation and implementation the following actions -tight procurement control (low prior review thresholds), regular supervision (quality and quantity by qualified supervision consultants), both off-site and through Bank missions to verify that the physical and financial parameters are reconciled, tight cost control (no price fluctuations and fixed price contracts) as well as provision for technical and financial audits. To this end, the Bank and USAID are cooperating to design appropriate safeguards and accounting mechanisms. Introduction
The financial management assessment was carried out in accordance with the Financial Management Practices Manual issued by the Financial Management Board on 3 November 2005. The objective o f the assessment was to determine whether the implementing entities have acceptable financial management arrangements, which will ensure: (1) the funds are used only for the intendedpurposes in an efficient and economical way, (2) the preparation o f accurate, reliable and timely periodic financial reports, and (3) safeguard the entity's assets.
The financial management assessment was carried by the Bank financial management team and included interviews with key staff (including financial comptroller) at the Ministry o f Public Works. Our assessment also draws on earlier work carried out under Economic Management and Development Program for Liberia.
Overview of ProgramandImplementationArrangements
The main objective o f the proposed emergency infrastructure project i s to provide the Government o f Liberia with emergency support to restore priority infrastructure. The Bank will provide this support through two main components, namely (i)emergency rehabilitation and repair o f critical infrastructure; this will be done through the emergency reconstruction, repair and improvement o f critical road and potable water supply infrastructure as well as support for electricity generation in Monrovia; and (ii) institutional capacity strengthening of the Ministry o f Public Works (MPW) and the LWSC; this seeks to strengthen MPW's capacity to carry out its roads development and maintenance management functions, establish effective monitoring and evaluation systems and operate effective longer term planning and budgeting mechanisms. The project will support the strengthening o f LWSC's functions o f revenue collection and metering maintenance.
The overall project oversight will be provided by a project steering committee, chaired by the MinistryofPublic Works and withmembership includingrepresentatives from Infrastructureand Basic Services Pillars, MOT, LWSC and MOF. The MPW will implement the Project through the creation o f a Special Implementation Unit (SIU) staffed with a combination o f competent MPW staff and selected technical assistance. The MPW has weak capacity to implement this project, hence the creation of the SIU. The S I U will support with re-establishing key functions, including procurement and contract management as well as, on a supporting basis to the PFMU, financial management functions, in the MPW. The S I U will be staffed with competent professionals with the required experience and qualifications.
The project will also support the establishment o f the PFMU in the MOF. The PFMU will be responsible for all financial management functions o f the SIU. The P F M U will be responsible for the day to day management o f project finances, will prepare project financial procedures manual, including the required IFRs and will put in place adequate arrangements for the auditing o f the project financial statements at the end o f each fiscal year.

Strengths and Weaknesses
Strengths
There i s a strong commitment by the MOF and the MPW to support the implementation o f the project. The SrU and the P F M U will be staffed by experienced and competent staff selected competitively to ensure speedy and timely implementation. These units will establish and maintain at all times appropriate financial management systems and practices that will meet the World Bank FMrequirements. Weaknesses
As inother post conflict countries, the overall fiduciary environment inLiberia i s very weak. The accounting staff at the M O F and M P W has limited experience with World Bank financial and disbursement procedures. The PFMU will be required to build FM capacity at the MOF and MPW. Successful implementation o f this project will require ownership and active support from Governmental authorities and less o f interference. This i s the greatest challenge that this project will face.
43  FMStaffing for the Project
The key staff that will have responsibility for the day to day financial management will be a professional accountant recruited as part o f the PFMU team. H e will initially be the PFMUHead and will be responsible for overall project management. Capacity o f accounting staff o f MOF will be built by the PFMU, in the areas of good financial management practices and World Bank FM and disbursement procedures. Some good performing accounting staff from the MOF will be attached to the PFMU for the transfer o f on thejob experience. These seconded staff will report to the head of the finance unit within the PFMU. The staff will receive training from the PFMU in the procedures established for the project and the Ministry. Project Financial Management
The PFMU will have an accountants/internal auditors with professional qualifications acceptable to IDA who will be responsible for the day to day financial management o f the project. They will report to the head o f the PFMU. The PFMU will establish an effective accounting system that provides for adequate segregation o f functions, capable o f recording all accounting transactions, and reporting correctly all assets and liabilities o f the project. The system should also be capable o f producing accurate periodic financial reports including IFRs and annual project financial statements.
The project will adopt the cash basis in the treatment and recording o f all transactions, In addition, the project will maintain a statement o f liabilities outstanding at all times to correctly reflect the projects indebtedness to suppliers and third parties. The financial management system should be documented in a financial accounting procedures manual which must be cleared by the World Bank.
The project will support the MPW and MOF through a PPF to enable them carry out certain minor activities until the two units have been established. The funds will be managed by the MOF. The staff will be supported by the finance staff o f an ongoing Bank funded project in Liberia, the Liberia Agency for Community Empowerment Project. The level o f PPF imprest will be small and will be for specified project preparation activities and will be agreed with the Bank, This will minimize the level o friskand also ensure that some activities are carried out prior to the engagement o f the SIU.
There will be an MOU signed within six months after effectiveness by the MOF and the M P W establishing the respective responsibilities o f the PFMU and the SW and defining the service standards associated with the project requirements that bothparties shall adhere to,
BudgetingArrangements
The project will prepare an annual budget for the project based upon the agreed program to be financed by the project. Most o f the activities o f the key components are already known and these will be included in the project annual budgets. The annual project budget will be reviewed and agreed with the World Bank, and No objections will be issued for only activities agreed in the budget.
Flow of FundsArrangements
The project arrangements are such that there will be no implementing entities at any decentralized location and the FPMU will therefore operate a centralized funds management system for the project. The S I U will send all requests for payment to the PFMU projects Accountant for
44  processing and payments. Where the single payment i s above a defined threshold the P F M U will process and send these to the Bank for direct payment to the third party. The PFMU will, on behalf o f the project submit withdrawal applications to the World Bank on a monthly basis. This will ensure the project has funds for operations at all times.
AuditingArrangements
Independent and qualified private sector auditors, acceptable to the Bank, would be selected by the PFMUto carry out the audit o f the project. The selection o f auditors shall be on competitive basis and in accordance with the Bank's guidelines and would be in place nine months after the effectiveness of the project.
The project financial statements includingmovements in the designated accounts will be audited inaccordance with InternationalStandards of Auditing(ISA) and a single opinion will be issued to cover the project financial statements, SOEs and the designated account, in accordance with the Bank's new audit policy.
The auditors' report and opinion inrespect o f the financial statements including the management letter would be furnishedto the World Bank within six months o f the close o f each fiscal year.
Reporting andMonitoring
The SIU will prepare quarterly IFRs in the areas o f finance, procurement, including complaints frombidders, and project progress. The reports are;
The Quarterly Financial Report (To be compiledand completedby the PFMU); which would consist o f a statement o f cash receipts by sources and expenditures by main expenditure classifications for the period and cumulatively; cash balances o f the project; and supporting schedules comparing actual and budgeted expenditures;
Quarterly Physical ProgressReport (To be compiledand completed by the SIU); include a narrative information and output indicators, linking financial information with physical progress and report on issues that require attention;
Quarterly Procurement Management Report (To be compiled and completed by the SIU); would consist o f information on procurement for goods and works and that for consultants' services and compliance with agreed procurement methods. The report compares procurement performance against the plan agreed at negotiations and appropriately updated at the end o f each quarter, The report should also provide any information on complaints by bidders, unsatisfactory performance by contractors and any contractual disputes.
The S I U will be responsible for preparing the IFR required to be produced under the project and will submit copies to the PFMUU and the Bank within 45 days o f the end o f each quarter. The content and format o f these reports will be agreed upon two months after the S I U and the P F M U have been established.
DisbursementArrangements
The proceeds o f the grant would be disbursed over four years. A period o f four (4) months after closing date would be allowed to make disbursements for expenditures incurred untilthe closing date o f the grant.
45  Use Statementof Expenditures(SOEs)
Disbursements for all expenditures would be against full documentation, except for items o f expenditures under contracts and purchase orders below US$200 000 equivalent each, for works, below US$lOO 000 equivalent each, for goods, below US$50 000 equivalent each for consulting firms, and US$lO 000 each for consultant services (individuals), training and incremental costs for which disbursements would be based on statement o f expenditures (SOEs). Supporting documentation for SOEs would be retained by the PFMU for review by IDA missions and external auditors.
DesignatedAccount @A)
The Grant Designated account (DA) o f the project will be managed by the PFMU. The grant DA can only be operated after the establishment o f the PFMU. It i s expected that prior to the recruitment o f the SIU and PFMU, a PPF Designated Account will be opened and operated by the MOF for initial project activities. The Designated Account for the project funds will be maintained in US$ and opened at a commercial bank, under terms and conditions satisfactory to the IDA. Upon grant effectiveness and submission o f a withdrawal application by the recipient, a sum of US$ 1.O million would be deposited by the Bank into the DA. Further deposits would be made into this account against withdrawal applications supported by appropriate documentation.

During the first year of the project implementation, intensive World Bank supervision will be required in order to ensure that the project financial management arrangements are in place and functioning. The financial management assessment has concluded that the risk for the project i s Substantial and actions have been put inplace to ensure that the identifiedrisks are adequately mitigated. The engagement of a professionally qualified accountant to head up the PFMU initially, the requirement for the establishment of systems and procedures by the S I U as part o f their assignment, and the agreed auditing arrangements for the project ensure that the project risks are minimized. Procurement for the proposed project would be carried out in accordance with the World Bank's "Guidelines: Procurement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits" dated M a y 2004; and "Guidelines: Selection and Employment o f Consultants by World Bank Recipients" dated M a y 2004, and the provisions stipulated in the Legal Agreement or any other method accepted by the Bank. B.AssessmentoftheMPW's capacityto implementprocurement
An assessment of the capacity o f the country to implement procurement actions was initially carried out by a World Bank team led by Mbuba Mbungu (Senior Procurement Specialist) in August 2004. The assessment reviewed to some extent the organizational structure for implementing projects and the interactionbetween the projects' staff responsible for procurement and the Government's relevant central unit for administrationand finance.
Since January 2006, Liberia has a new Procurement Law that i s based on the Bank's procurement guidelines. The Law lists procedures that need to be complied with. Namely, the Procuring Entity at the MPW has to be involved in the process o f procuring contracts. Contracts will be signed by the designated officials o f the MPW and beneficiary agencies, which will then be responsible for the management o f the contracts.
The procurement capacity in the Ministry o f Public Works i s very limited therefore there i s need to develop it gradually but rapidly. Firstly, a Special Implementation Unit (SIU) was created and it will be staffed with a combination o f technical assistance and competent MPW staff. The SIU will have responsibilities in the areas o f project management, procurement, and financial management. Its responsibilities will include (a) assuring steady progress o f the procurement in accordance with an implementation schedule reviewed and approved by the World Bank, and (b) ensuring satisfactory implementation o f activities included inall contract.
At a minimum,the SIU will include a procurement specialist with engineering background and a financial management specialist who, together, will implement the necessary procurement activities. The specialist will; (i) plan and process all procurement (ii) the implementation monitor of the procurement plans, and (iii)train staff o f the implementing agencies in the use o f procurement procedures agreed under the project, including compliance with World bank Procurement Guidelines. doc.abstracts: The Liberia Emergency Infrastructure Project will, on an emergency basis, assist the Government to reconstruct parts of the country's devastated infrastructure. These actions will help revive the economy and reintegrate the country by restoring vital transport links throughout the country. It will also support the improvement of living conditions in the capital, Monrovia, by restoring and expanding potable water supply services and improve the provision of emergency power to parts of Monrovia. The risks to the project are substantial. This will be the first large Bank-supported project to be implemented by Government. As such, implementation needs to be carefully planned to mitigate environmental and social risks as well as financial and procurement risks. The international Development Association will work closely with Government to ensure that risks are identified and mitigated appropriately. The major risks are: (1) limited capacity to prepare and manage the Project within the Ministry of Pubic Works; 2i) private sector interest in civil works contracts is not forthcoming; (3) donor coordination may be difficult in the emergency environment; and (4) corruption and mismanagement.
